content.description: Surprisingly fun for a small boulder. Sit start on the juggy ledge and climb the arete. The face to the right of the start is OFF. Consider yourself topped out when you're standing with your face in the honeysuckle. Careful descending the slab with the lichen. Definitely don't grab the rotten pine tree.
content.location: 40m downstream and on the opposite bank from the Culvert Boulders.

content.description: Sit start on the lower right flake. Big move out left to the crimp. Bump to the crack and walk it up.
content.location: 50 yards downstream from Culvert Boulders, across the river.

content.description: Start with the to side pulls and walk you feet up the horizontal. Nice jug at the top.
content.location: Just right of Compression

content.description: Start on the small crimps and move to big the jug.
content.location: On the far left of The Culvert Boulders which is located by the cross stream.

content.description: Start matched in the hole that goes all the way through the Boulder. Go up to good hold and then find the crimp out right. Top out to finish
content.location: About 20 yards upstream from the culvert boulder

content.description: Same start as "Slice" with a starting foot on the second hold of it as well. Move up utilizing a crystal crimp and jugs.
content.location: The arete on the starting holds of "Slice" at the boulders across and downstream from the culvert boulders.

content.description: Start on the horizontal
content.location: Just right of Roof Bar

content.description: Sit start with both hands in the crack. Layback for a few moves until finding good crimps on the face. Easy topout.
content.location: On the right side of the Barock Climbing Obama boulder

content.description:
Not only named for the graffiti and the shape of the rock...

 Start on the large flake at the bottom of the left arete. Traverse right on increasingly small crimps until you can make a big move up to a small jug. Go left and slightly up to another small jug, and then top out from there. If you get on this, please leave your grade impression; seeking more data points.

 Also looks like there's a variation of roughly the same difficulty that traverses entirely across the face, and then comes back up the right arete/lip to top out in the same spot, though I haven't sent it yet.
content.protection: Landing is mostly level, but sandy. The only big rock is, naturally, under the crux. I used two pads - one to cover the rock under the big move up, and one to cover the tree behind it, and you'll want at least a towel to wipe off sand at the start, too.
content.location: About 50m downstream and on the opposite bank from the Culvert Boulders. The climbable face faces downstream. I found walking on the large fallen tree next to the water is the best way to access it.

content.description: Used the side pull to move to the big jug to the left.
content.location: Just Right of Unhanded.

content.description: Start in the sharp, corner block. Reach around the roof, gain a knee bar, move up to quartz nubs.
content.location: A quarter mile upstream from and on the same side of the creek as The Culvert Boulders.

content.description: Sit start using large jug. Throw to a nice hold on the top of the rock.
content.location: Just right of Side-to-Jug. In the Culvert Boulders

content.description: A pretty fun jug traverse and top out.
content.location: Behind Roof Bar and Smooth Feet

content.description: Start as per Helen Smirren, but move to the right and top out on the sloping section.My beta: Right to a good crimp, left to the bad gaston directly above the start, and right foot on the jug out right. I used a pebble as an intermediate for my right hand to gain the good sloper out right. Then work up using the textured section and whatever slopers out right let you get to the victory jug/sloper at the top of the boulder.Not certain of the grade, so I look forward to other thoughts.
content.location: Upstream side of the Culvert Boulder.

content.description: Start on the side pull and move up to a small crimps.
content.protection: Pads and spotter. You probably want a couple of to build up a nice landing.
content.location: On the back side of The Culvert Boulders.

content.description: Start as per Unhanded on the rail, but go directly up using a small pockety sloper and a large jug out left.I feel like this must have been done before, so if it has another FA/name, please let me know.
content.location: On the Culvert Boulder at the trail junction.

content.description: Same start as Forklift, same small boulder is off for feet. Go straight up the arete.
content.location: 25ish meters downstream and on the opposite side of the stream from the Culvert Boulders.

content.description: Start on the far left and follow the crack up and right until you hit the intersection of all the cracks, then follow the more vertical crack (see the picture) to top out. The smaller rock there at the bottom is off for feet. Or use it if you want. Just makes it easier than V1.
content.location: 25ish meters downstream and on the opposite side of the stream from the Culvert Boulders.

content.description: Start as per Slice, go directly up from the jug rail to a slopey crimp. Pop left to a tooth in a seam, then top out directly above. Contrived eliminate (arete is off), but natural movement.
content.location: Same boulder as Slice.

content.description: Start low on the horizontal, and move up.
content.protection: Pads and spotter. The landing is very steep
content.location: On the right side (if hiking up stream) of the Cross Country Trail about 30 feet up hill off the trail. If you come to the cross stream and The Culvert Boulders you have gone too far.

content.description: Move up the dihedral and then to the top.
content.location: Between The Culvert Boulders and Roof Bar, 300 yards upstream of the Culvert Boulders, 130 yards downstream of the Roof Bar.

content.description: Located in the shady a Pohick Creek drainage, a few gneiss, spray painted boulders that make for a couple problems.  This isn't a great climbing destination, but if you have no-where better to go, it's something.
